conversation:
Persuader: Hey, how are you doing, have you ever heard of a charity called Save the Children?
Persuadee: No I havent.
Persuadee: What is it about?
Persuader: It's an international organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries, does that sound like something you'd get behind?
Persuadee: No thank you.
Persuader: May I ask why?
Persuader: Your help could really make a difference in a child's life, think of a child who didn't have enough to eat, just a small bit of help may have saved them, are you sure you're not interested?
Persuadee: I am already making a difference in many children lives.
Persuader: That's great, it sounds like it's an issue you really care about then, why not put some of that effort into a charity that's doing really great work like Save the Children?
Persuadee: I have donated 15 years of my life to charity
Persuader: I'm not asking you to donate years of your life, just a couple of cents if possible, is that something you could possibly do tonight?
Persuadee: No thank you
Persuader: You're probably on a computer right now, so you probably have quite a bit of money yourself, don't you think you could spare maybe 25 cents for some needy children around the world?
Persuadee: No thank you
Persuader: Do you have children yourself?
Persuader: What if your children were in a position these kids are in, wouldn't you want someone to help them?

conversation:
Persuader: Hi there
Persuadee: Hello
Persuader: Have you heard of the Save the Children charity?
Persuadee: I actually have not.
Persuadee: What do they do to help children?
Persuader: It is an international organization that helps protect and promote rights for childrens and provides for them in suffering conditions - such as lack of basic needs, like water, clothing, and food.
Persuadee: I'm glad a charity like that exists internationally.
Persuader: It's for a great cause.
Persuader: Children are the future and unfortunately too many of them don't get the quality of life that we take advantage of today.
Persuader: Sometimes we're in a better place and we have to do what we can to help their conditions a little bit.
Persuader: Even little bits can go a long way, you know?
Persuadee: it does, and charities can go further with the amount of money donated.
Persuader: Absolutely.
Persuader: I remember seeing ads on the television about it and it breaks my hear to see children so sad and suffering in conditions that they live in.
Persuader: I haven't personally witnessed experiences first hand, however, it comes down to basic human needs.
Persuadee: It's sad to think being born in the wrong conditions can have such a lifelong impact.
Persuader: Exactly.
Persuader: It's not like we really get the choice of how/when/where we are born.
Persuader: It's a matter of chance.
Persuader: It's unfair to be born into conditions like that.
Persuadee: Hopefully, more the people born more lucky can lend a hand.

conversation:
Persuader: Hello!
Persuader: How're you doing today?
Persuadee: Hey, kind of tired but overall good.
Persuadee: How are you?
Persuader: I'm doing alright.
Persuader: I just had a thought on my mind that I wanted to ask you about
Persuadee: Yea?
Persuadee: Go for it.
Persuader: Do you donate when you get the chance?
Persuader: I was thinking about how everywhere you go, they ask you to donate .50 here and your change there.
Persuader: I think I need to actually start donating.
Persuader: How does it make you feel?
Persuader: Do you donate?
Persuadee: I don't like to donate to for profit businesses.
Persuadee: I feel like they'll just take my donation and get their tax credit.
Persuader: How do you feel about Save the Children?
Persuader: My nephew had to get taken into the hospital not too long ago and I just got the letter in the mail saying they used Save the Childrens donation money to help him.
Persuader: I'm thinking about donating to them.
Persuadee: I'm sorry to hear about your nephew?
Persuadee: What happened, if you don't mind me asking.
Persuader: We found out the hard way that he has actual celiacs (sorry I can't spell too well) and he has an allergic reaction to the cake on his birthday.
Persuader: He went through a TON of testing and that's how they caught it.
Persuader: He has to stay overnight at the hospital for a few weeks and his parents just couldn't afford it.
Persuader: That's when Save the Children came around to help
Persuadee: Oh my gosh.
Persuadee: I am so sorry to hear about the little guy and how his birthday, too.
Persuadee: How did Save the Children help?
Persuader: They helped cover the bills for it since he's in Africa.
Persuader: He's doing much better now though!
Persuadee: Oh wow.
Persuadee: All the way in Africa.
Persuadee: I'm really glad to hear that.

conversation:
Persuader: Hello!
Persuadee: Hey
Persuader: So, are you interested in charities that help save the children?
Persuadee: Which children?
Persuader: What does the charity do exactly?
Persuader: Instead of the typical charities that help children in a far away land, we here use state of the art location technology to help children in need right in your own community so you can see your money at work personally
Persuadee: What would my money do exactly

Persuadee: Okay, that sounds reasonable
Persuader: We appreciate your willingness to donate to this local cause, how much of a gratuity will you be offering today?

conversation:

Persuadee: I think that's great!

conversation:
Persuader: Hello, have you heard of Save The Children?
Persuadee: I think so, it sounds familiar.
Persuadee: it is a nonprofit charity if i recall.
Persuadee: What exactly do they do?
Persuader: Save The Children helps kids from around the world by taking contributions from generous patrons. Kids from countries that have been stricken by poverty, violence, and other blights.
Persuadee: What countries has the charity worked in recently?
Persuader: Well, we have programs set up in 120 countries in total right now.
Persuader: Some of our most recent campaigns involve Myanmar - in Rohingya where parents and their children have been forced to flee because of violence to surrounding countries. In the largest refugee camp stationed in Bangladesh, there are an estimated 915,000 children and adults taking shelter.
Persuadee: Wow that sounds like a really robust program.
Persuadee: How long has Save the Children been around?
Persuader: It was founded in 1919, on April 15th in London - UK.
Persuadee: Do you work for Save the Children or do you just volunteer for the charity?
Persuader: I do not work for them, I work on behalf of them.
Persuader: That is why I'm talking to you today.
Persuader: These children need help, and could use it from generous people like you.
Persuader: A meal, an education, an opportunity like everyone else, that is all these kids want.
Persuader: Even one cent will add up to help a child in need, but if you wish you may donate up to 2 dollars.
Persuader: For every cent you donate it will come directly from your task payment.
Persuadee: I love to help charities that serve a good cause and I would love to donate but I do have one question.
Persuadee: What is the portion of donations that goes to children versus the portion that goes to administration or other expenses
Persuader: Sure, absolutely. In 2017, 86% went to Program services - or services that directly help aid these children. 9% went towards fundraising efforts, and 5% went towards our Management & other general costs. In 2018 we anticipate similar numbers.
Persuadee: That's pretty impressive!
Persuadee: Not too many charities can claim such a strong commitment to the cause.
Persuader: We do it for them, not for ourselves.
Persuader: And we hope our numbers reflect that amount of love and effort that goes toward what we do.
Persuadee: I'd be willing to donate $1 to Save the Children.

conversation:
Persuader: Donate to Save the Children, please.
Persuader: Think about those poor kids.
Persuadee: Well tell me a little bit more about the charity.
Persuader: It's really all in the name.
Persuader: You have a moral responsibility.
Persuadee: A lot of charities are just a name and they don't do what they promise.
Persuadee: How do I know my money will go where it supposed to?
Persuader: They're a world-famous trustworthy charity.
Persuader: If they were fraudulent or misallocating funds, surely there'd have been a scandal.
Persuadee: Ok.
Persuadee: So why do they deserve my money as opposed to other charities like St Judes or the Red Cross>
Persuader: Of course you can donate to other charities.
Persuader: It's not necessarily a zero-sum game.
Persuader: I can tell you, however, that Save the Children is, in a way, more immediate in helping people (as opposed to fighting disease like St Jude's) and delivers services similar to the Red Cross, but directed toward children.
Persuader: So, please: think of the children!
Persuadee: Do they help kids in the US?
Persuadee: I like to help people that are close to home.
Persuader: Their assistance is directed toward children in developing countries, where, unlike most of the US, children are totally deprived of opportunity and basic services.
Persuader: Though you, being the generous person you are, like helping those at home, is there a reason not to help children abroad?
Persuadee: I don't mind helping those abroad.
Persuadee: But there are a lot kids here in the US who deal with poverty.
Persuadee: So it's not that I don't care about the children elsewhere, just want to help those at home first.
